title: Home Prices in Prime Central London Bottoming Out
text:
Home values in prime central London were more resilient in the third quarter than at any time in the past four years, according to new figures from Savills on Tuesday.



Average home prices across an exclusive swath of inner London fell only 0.3% in the third quarter compared to the previous three months, the smallest quarterly decline since 2015, according to an index from the London-based brokerage. It’s a sign that the market’s downturn has begun to bottom out, analysts at Savills said.

Home prices across London’s poshest postcodes, areas like Kensington and Chelsea, Westminster and the City of London, averaged £4.4 million (US$5.41 million) in the third quarter, a 3% decline from the same time last year. On a square footage basis, homes traded for an average £1,750 per square foot in the third quarter.



The latest figures mean homes in this area are more than 20% cheaper than they were at the market’s last peak in 2014, according to the report.



“This broad price correction across prime central London is comparable with falls seen post-[great financial crisis] and in the downturns of the early ’80s and early ’90s, suggesting the market is now close to a full re-pricing,” said Lucian Cook, head of Savills residential research.



But broader economic and political uncertainty surrounding Brexit, which has become even more decisive in recent weeks as the country approaches an Oct. 31 exit deadline, create the primary obstacle to improved sales and pricing, according to a majority of Savills’s London agents.

“We expect buyer and seller caution to prevail through the remainder of the year as negotiations with the EU continue. The prospect of a general election only adds to this,” Mr. Cook said in the report.



In the meantime, international buyers are acting as a counterweight to the drop-off in domestic demand for homes in London.

“There’s a growing pool of domestic and international money waiting to exploit a perceived buying opportunity,” he added.
